paccabyattha.comments: The word appears to be an aorist form of 'paccabujjhati' (to awaken, understand), used here in the context of penetrating or realizing the sorrowless state (asokaṁ padaṁ). The prefix 'paccā' intensifies the meaning of the root √budh (to awaken).
paccabyattha.translation_1: The sorrowless state that you have penetrated,
paccabyattha.translation_2: The sorrowless state that you have penetrated,

mātarī.comments: The word 'mātarī' is in the locative singular, indicating 'about mother' or 'in the mother' in the given context.

jānati.comments: In the given context, 'jānati' is used in the negative ('na jānati'), meaning 'he does not know' or 'he did not know' (past tense is implied by context). The verb is in present tense but the English translation suggests past tense, which is common in Pāḷi where context determines time reference.
jānati.translation_1: He did not know at Codanā;

apavilānā.comments: The word 'apavilānā' appears to be an indeclinable adverb formed with the prefix 'apa-' (away, off) and possibly related to 'vilāna' (taking, removing). In the given context, it seems to mean 'without taking' or 'without removing', as the English translation suggests 'without taking'.
apavilānā.translation_1: Here the nine on without taking,

sampaṭipāṭetvā.comments: The word is an absolutive (gerund) form, indicating an action completed before another action. In this context, it refers to the act of closing or stitching the suture in the skull before applying the ointment.
sampaṭipāṭetvā.example_1: Sibbiniṁ sampaṭipāṭetvā sīsacchaviṁ sibbitvā ālepaṁ adāsi.
sampaṭipāṭetvā.translation_1: He then closed the suture in the skull, sewed the skin back together, and applied an ointment.

kaṇḍusakaṃ.meaning_2: strips of cloth for marking; reinforcing strips
kaṇḍusakaṃ.comments: The term appears to refer to strips of cloth used for marking or reinforcing garments, likely for practical or mending purposes in the monastic context.
kaṇḍusakaṃ.example_1: Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, aggaḷaṁ tunnaṁ ovaṭṭikaṁ kaṇḍusakaṁ daḷhīkamman”ti.
kaṇḍusakaṃ.translation_1: And I allow patches, mending, hems, strips of cloth for marking, and strengthening.”

visākhāvatthu.meaning_2: the account of Visākhā; the case of Visākhā
visākhāvatthu.comments: The compound 'visākhāvatthu' refers to an account or case related to Visākhā, a chief female disciple of the Buddha. The context suggests it is a narrative or story about her.

nikkhittacīvarā.meaning_2: with robes discarded; having robes set aside
nikkhittacīvarā.comments: The compound describes someone who has set aside or discarded their robes, as seen in the context where monks bathe in the rain without robes.
nikkhittacīvarā.example_1: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paṭissuṇitvā nikkhittacīvarā kāyaṁ ovassāpenti.
nikkhittacīvarā.translation_1: Saying, “Yes, sir,” they took off their robes and bathed in the rain.
nikkhittacīvarā.example_2: Atha kho visākhāya migāramātuyā paṇḍitāya viyattāya medhāviniyā etadahosi—“nissaṁsayaṁ kho ayyā nikkhittacīvarā kāyaṁ ovassāpenti.
nikkhittacīvarā.translation_2: Being wise and discerning, Visākhā thought, “No doubt the venerables are bathing naked in the rain.

nikkhittacīvare.meaning_2: with robes discarded; without robes; having laid aside robes
nikkhittacīvare.comments: The context shows monks bathing naked in the rain, so 'nikkhittacīvare' refers to having discarded or laid aside their robes. The compound combines the past participle 'nikkhitta' (laid aside) with 'cīvare' (robes, locative plural).
nikkhittacīvare.example_1: “Evaṁ, ayye”ti kho sā dāsī visākhāya migāramātuyā paṭissuṇitvā ārāmaṁ gantvā addasa bhikkhū nikkhittacīvare kāyaṁ ovassāpente, disvāna—
nikkhittacīvare.translation_1: Saying, “Yes, ma’am,” she went to the monastery and saw the monks bathing naked in the rain. She thought,
nikkhittacīvare.example_2: Atha kho sā, bhante, dāsī ārāmaṁ gantvā addasa bhikkhū nikkhittacīvare kāyaṁ ovassāpente, disvāna—

ovassāpente.meaning_2: causes to make wet through rain; bathing (in the rain)
ovassāpente.comments: In context, the monks are bathing naked in the rain, hence 'ovassāpente' refers to them making their bodies wet by the rain.
ovassāpente.example_1: “Evaṁ, ayye”ti kho sā dāsī visākhāya migāramātuyā paṭissuṇitvā ārāmaṁ gantvā addasa bhikkhū nikkhittacīvare kāyaṁ ovassāpente, disvāna—
ovassāpente.translation_1: Saying, “Yes, ma’am,” she went to the monastery and saw the monks bathing naked in the rain. She thought,
ovassāpente.example_2: Atha kho sā, bhante, dāsī ārāmaṁ gantvā addasa bhikkhū nikkhittacīvare kāyaṁ ovassāpente, disvāna—

kallakāyā.meaning_2: invigorated in body; refreshed in body; healthy in body
kallakāyā.comments: The compound 'kallakāyā' (feminine plural) describes the monks as being invigorated or refreshed in body after cooling themselves, indicating a state of physical well-being or readiness.
kallakāyā.example_1: Atha kho te bhikkhū gattāni sītiṁ karitvā kallakāyā cīvarāni gahetvā yathāvihāraṁ pavisiṁsu.
kallakāyā.translation_1: When the monks had cooled their bodies and felt invigorated, they took their robes and entered their dwellings.
kallakāyā.example_2: “nissaṁsayaṁ kho ayyā gattāni sītiṁ karitvā kallakāyā cīvarāni gahetvā yathāvihāraṁ paviṭṭhā.

jaṇṇukamattesupi.comments: The compound 'jaṇṇukamattesupi' is in the locative case, indicating location ('in knee-deep water'). The word 'api' adds emphasis ('even'). The construction combines 'jaṇṇuka' (knee) with 'matta' (measure) to form 'knee-deep'.
jaṇṇukamattesupi.example_1: Tathāgatassa mahiddhikatā mahānubhāvatā, yatra hi nāma jaṇṇukamattesupi oghesu pavattamānesu, kaṭimattesupi oghesu pavattamānesu, na hi nāma ekabhikkhussapi pādā vā cīvarāni vā allāni bhavissantī”ti—
jaṇṇukamattesupi.translation_1: The water is flowing knee-deep, even waist-deep, yet not a single monk has wet feet or wet robes.”

vīthikusalo.meaning_2: skilled in the streets; familiar with the roads
vīthikusalo.comments: The compound 'vīthikusala' combines 'vīthi' (street/road) and 'kusala' (skilled), referring to someone who is adept at navigating streets, as seen in the context of monks knowing their alms route.
vīthikusalo.example_1: Puna caparaṁ, bhante, āgantuko bhikkhu na vīthikusalo na gocarakusalo kilanto piṇḍāya carati.
vīthikusalo.translation_1: Also, not knowing the streets or where to go, newly-arrived monks will get exhausted while walking for alms.
vīthikusalo.example_2: So me āgantukabhattaṁ bhuñjitvā vīthikusalo gocarakusalo akilanto piṇḍāya carissati.
vīthikusalo.translation_2: But if they eat a meal from me, they will get to know the streets and where to go for alms, and they will avoid getting exhausted.

bhattacchedaṃ.meaning_2: cutting off of meals; deprivation of food
bhattacchedaṃ.comments: The compound 'bhattacchedaṃ' refers to the act of depriving someone of their meal, as seen in the context where the sick monks would not receive their meals on time.
bhattacchedaṃ.example_1: Puna caparaṁ, bhante, gilānupaṭṭhāko bhikkhu attano bhattaṁ pariyesamāno gilānassa ussūre bhattaṁ nīharissati, bhattacchedaṁ karissati.
bhattacchedaṃ.translation_1: Also, if the monks who nurse the sick have to get their own meals, they won’t be able to bring back meals for the sick until after midday, and then the sick won’t be able to eat.
bhattacchedaṃ.example_2: So me gilānupaṭṭhākabhattaṁ bhuñjitvā gilānassa kālena bhattaṁ nīharissati, bhattacchedaṁ na karissati.
bhattacchedaṃ.translation_2: But if they eat a meal from me, they’ll be able to bring back meals for the sick in good time, and the sick will be able to eat.

balabhāvanā.meaning_2: development of spiritual powers; cultivation of strength
balabhāvanā.comments: The compound 'balabhāvanā' refers to the cultivation or development of spiritual powers (bala), which is a key aspect of Buddhist practice as seen in the context of developing faculties and factors of awakening.
balabhāvanā.example_1: Sā me bhavissati indriyabhāvanā balabhāvanā bojjhaṅgabhāvanā.
balabhāvanā.translation_1: In this way I’ll develop the spiritual faculties, the spiritual powers, and the factors of awakening.

bojjhaṅgabhāvanā.meaning_2: developing the factors of awakening; cultivating the elements of enlightenment
bojjhaṅgabhāvanā.comments: The compound refers to the practice of cultivating the seven factors of enlightenment (bojjhaṅga), which are essential for awakening. The context shows it is grouped with other developmental practices (indriyabhāvanā, balabhāvanā).
bojjhaṅgabhāvanā.example_1: Sā me bhavissati indriyabhāvanā balabhāvanā bojjhaṅgabhāvanā.
bojjhaṅgabhāvanā.translation_1: In this way I’ll develop the spiritual faculties, the spiritual powers, and the factors of awakening.

dadatippamoditā.meaning_2: rejoicing in giving; delighting in offering
dadatippamoditā.comments: The compound combines 'dada' (giving), 'tippa' (intense), and 'modita' (rejoiced), emphasizing intense joy in the act of giving, particularly food and drink as per the context.

sīlūpapannā.meaning_2: endowed with virtue; possessing moral conduct; having ethical behavior
sīlūpapannā.comments: The compound 'sīlūpapannā' combines 'sīla' (virtue) and 'upapanna' (possessed of), describing a disciple who is endowed with virtue. The context emphasizes the moral integrity of the disciple in relation to the Buddha ('sugatassa sāvikā').
sīlūpapannā.translation_1: A virtuous disciple of the Accomplished One,

sokanudaṃ.comments: The compound 'sokanudaṃ' is a bahuvrīhi compound meaning 'that which dispels sorrow'. In the given sentence, it functions adjectivally to describe something (implied) that removes grief, aligning with the English translation 'eliminates sadness'.
sokanudaṃ.translation_1: It leads to heaven, eliminates sadness, and brings bliss.

visākhābhāṇavāro.meaning_2: section for recitation on Visākhā; recitation cycle related to Visākhā
visākhābhāṇavāro.comments: The compound refers to a specific section of scripture dedicated to the teachings or stories related to Visākhā, a chief female disciple of the Buddha. The context indicates the conclusion of this recitation section.
visākhābhāṇavāro.translation_1: The section for recitation on Visākhā is finished.

nisīdanādianujānana.meaning_2: the allowance of a sitting mat; permission for a sitting mat
nisīdanādianujānana.comments: The word is a compound consisting of 'nisīdana' (sitting mat), 'ādi' (beginning with, etc.), and 'anujānanā' (allowance, permission). The context suggests it refers to the permission granted for the use of a sitting mat.
nisīdanādianujānana.translation_1: 19. The allowance of a sitting mat

kāyaguttiyā.meaning_2: protection of the body; guarding the body
kāyaguttiyā.comments: The compound 'kāyagutti' is used in the context of protecting or guarding the body, as seen in the Vinaya passage where it refers to the use of a sitting mat for bodily protection.
kāyaguttiyā.example_1: Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, kāyaguttiyā cīvaraguttiyā senāsanaguttiyā nisīdanan”ti.
kāyaguttiyā.translation_1: And, monks, I allow a sitting mat to protect the body, the robes, and the furniture.”

cīvaraguttiyā.meaning_2: protection of robes; guarding of robes
cīvaraguttiyā.comments: A compound formed from 'cīvara' (robe) and 'gutti' (protection), referring specifically to the protection or care of monastic robes as mentioned in the Vinaya context.
cīvaraguttiyā.example_1: Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, kāyaguttiyā cīvaraguttiyā senāsanaguttiyā nisīdanan”ti.
cīvaraguttiyā.translation_1: And, monks, I allow a sitting mat to protect the body, the robes, and the furniture.”

senāsanaguttiyā.meaning_2: protection of furniture; guarding of lodging
senāsanaguttiyā.comments: The compound 'senāsanagutti' refers to the protection or guarding of furniture or lodging, as seen in the context where it is listed alongside 'kāyaguttiyā' (protection of the body) and 'cīvaraguttiyā' (protection of robes). The term is a feminine abstract noun formed from the combination of 'senāsana' (furniture/lodging) and 'gutti' (protection).
senāsanaguttiyā.example_1: Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, kāyaguttiyā cīvaraguttiyā senāsanaguttiyā nisīdanan”ti.
senāsanaguttiyā.translation_1: And, monks, I allow a sitting mat to protect the body, the robes, and the furniture.”

yāvamahantaṃ.meaning_2: as large as; as great as; as much as
yāvamahantaṃ.comments: The word is a compound of 'yāva' (as much as) and 'mahanta' (large/great), used here to indicate the extent or size of the sheet that is allowed to be made.
yāvamahantaṃ.example_1: “Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, yāvamahantaṁ paccattharaṇaṁ ākaṅkhati tāvamahantaṁ paccattharaṇaṁ kātun”ti.
yāvamahantaṃ.translation_1: “I allow you to make a sheet as large as you like.”

mukhapuñchanacoḷaṃ.meaning_2: towel for wiping the face; washcloth
mukhapuñchanacoḷaṃ.comments: The word is a compound consisting of 'mukha' (face), 'puñchana' (wiping), and 'coḷa' (cloth), used in the context of a cloth for wiping the face, as seen in the example where Visākhā offers it to the Buddha.
mukhapuñchanacoḷaṃ.example_1: Atha kho visākhā migāramātā mukhapuñchanacoḷaṁ ādāya yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
mukhapuñchanacoḷaṃ.translation_1: On one occasion Visākhā took a washcloth and went to the Buddha. She bowed, sat down,
mukhapuñchanacoḷaṃ.example_2: “paṭiggaṇhātu me, bhante, bhagavā mukhapuñchanacoḷaṁ, yaṁ mamassa dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
mukhapuñchanacoḷaṃ.translation_2: “Sir, please accept this washcloth for my long-lasting benefit and happiness.”

mukhapuñchanacoḷakanti.meaning_2: towel for wiping the face; washcloth
mukhapuñchanacoḷakanti.comments: The word is a compound of 'mukha' (face), 'puñchana' (wiping), and 'coḷaka' (cloth), referring to a cloth used for wiping the face. The context shows it is allowed as a practical item for monks.

khomapilotikā.meaning_2: old linen cloth; rag made of linen
khomapilotikā.comments: The word is a compound of 'khoma' (linen) and 'pilotikā' (old cloth/rag), referring to an old piece of linen cloth left with Ānanda.
khomapilotikā.example_1: Rojassa mallassa khomapilotikā āyasmato ānandassa hatthe nikkhittā hoti.
khomapilotikā.translation_1: Roja had left an old linen cloth with Ānanda,

khomapilotikāya.comments: The word is a compound of 'khoma' (linen) and 'pilotikā' (rag), referring to a piece of old linen cloth, which fits the context of Ānanda needing such a cloth.
khomapilotikāya.example_1: Āyasmato ca ānandassa khomapilotikāya attho hoti.
khomapilotikāya.translation_1: and it so happened that Ānanda needed such a cloth.

parikkhāracoḷakanti.meaning_2: cloth for requisites; rag for equipment
parikkhāracoḷakanti.comments: The compound refers to a piece of cloth specifically designated for use with requisites (parikkhāra), likely for wrapping or protecting them. The diminutive 'coḷaka' suggests it's a small or secondary piece of cloth.

pacchimavikappanupagacīvarādikathā.meaning_2: Discussion of the smallest robe-cloth that can be assigned to another, etc.
pacchimavikappanupagacīvarādikathā.comments: This is a compound term from the Vinaya texts, specifically discussing the rules regarding the smallest permissible size of robe-cloth that can be assigned or shared among monks. The term is a combination of several elements, each contributing to its specific meaning in the context of monastic discipline.
pacchimavikappanupagacīvarādikathā.translation_1: 20. Discussion of the smallest robe-cloth that can be assigned to another, etc.

mukhapuñchanacoḷanti.meaning_2: cloth for wiping the face; washcloth
mukhapuñchanacoḷanti.comments: The compound 'mukhapuñchanacoḷa' is a combination of 'mukha' (face), 'puñchana' (wiping), and 'coḷa' (cloth), referring to a cloth specifically used for wiping the face, as indicated by the context of monastic requisites.
mukhapuñchanacoḷanti.example_1: “yāni tāni bhagavatā anuññātāni ticīvaranti vā vassikasāṭikāti vā nisīdananti vā paccattharaṇanti vā kaṇḍuppaṭicchādīti vā mukhapuñchanacoḷanti vā parikkhāracoḷanti vā, sabbāni tāni adhiṭṭhātabbāni nu kho, udāhu vikappetabbānī”ti?
mukhapuñchanacoḷanti.translation_1: “These things that have been allowed by the Buddha—the three robes, the rainy-season robe, the sitting mat, the sheet, the itch-covering cloth, the washcloth, and the cloth for requisites—are they all to be determined or to be assigned to another?”

parikkhāracoḷanti.meaning_2: cloth for requisites; rag for necessities
parikkhāracoḷanti.comments: The compound 'parikkhāracoḷa' refers to a specific type of cloth used for requisites, likely for practical purposes like wrapping or covering items. In the context of the Vinaya, it is one of the allowable items for monks.
parikkhāracoḷanti.example_1: “yāni tāni bhagavatā anuññātāni ticīvaranti vā vassikasāṭikāti vā nisīdananti vā paccattharaṇanti vā kaṇḍuppaṭicchādīti vā mukhapuñchanacoḷanti vā parikkhāracoḷanti vā, sabbāni tāni adhiṭṭhātabbāni nu kho, udāhu vikappetabbānī”ti?
parikkhāracoḷanti.translation_1: “These things that have been allowed by the Buddha—the three robes, the rainy-season robe, the sitting mat, the sheet, the itch-covering cloth, the washcloth, and the cloth for requisites—are they all to be determined or to be assigned to another?”

vikappetuṃ.meaning_2: to assign to another; to transfer ownership; to give away
vikappetuṃ.comments: The word is used in the context of Vinaya rules regarding the assignment of robes and other monastic requisites. It implies the act of transferring ownership or assigning something to another person, which is regulated in monastic discipline.
vikappetuṃ.translation_1: “You should determine the three robes, not assign them to another;
vikappetuṃ.example_2: vassikasāṭikaṁ vassānaṁ cātumāsaṁ adhiṭṭhātuṁ, tato paraṁ vikappetuṁ;
vikappetuṃ.translation_2: you should determine the rainy-season robe for the four months of the rainy season, and apart from that assign it to another;

parikkhāracoḷaṃ.meaning_2: cloth for requisites; cloth used for necessities
parikkhāracoḷaṃ.comments: The compound 'parikkhāracoḷa' refers to a specific type of cloth designated for requisites, likely used by monastics for practical purposes. The context suggests it is a functional item that should not be reassigned to others.
parikkhāracoḷaṃ.translation_1: you should determine a cloth for requisites, not assign it to another.”

caturaṅgulavitthataṃ.meaning_2: four fingers wide; measuring four fingers in width
caturaṅgulavitthataṃ.comments: The compound describes the width of the robe-cloth as four fingerbreadths, combining 'caturaṅgula' (four fingers) and 'vitthata' (spread out, wide). The context specifies the dimensions for assigning robe-cloth.
caturaṅgulavitthataṃ.example_1: “Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, āyāmena aṭṭhaṅgulaṁ sugataṅgulena caturaṅgulavitthataṁ pacchimaṁ cīvaraṁ vikappetun”ti.
caturaṅgulavitthataṃ.translation_1: “The smallest robe-cloth you should assign to another is one that’s eight standard fingerbreadths long and four wide.”

paṃsukūlakato.meaning_2: made of rags from a rubbish heap; composed of discarded cloth
paṃsukūlakato.comments: The word 'paṃsukūlakata' is a compound adjective describing the robes of Venerable Mahākassapa as being made from discarded rags, emphasizing the ascetic practice of using humble materials.
paṃsukūlakato.example_1: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmato mahākassapassa paṁsukūlakato garuko hoti.
paṃsukūlakato.translation_1: At that time Venerable Mahākassapa’s rag robes were heavy.

suttalūkhaṃ.meaning_2: rough mending with thread; coarse stitching
suttalūkhaṃ.comments: The compound 'suttalūkhaṃ' refers to a rough or coarse mending done with thread, as allowed by the Buddha in the Vinaya context. It combines 'sutta' (thread) and 'lūkha' (rough/coarse), indicating a practical allowance for basic repairs.
suttalūkhaṃ.translation_1: “I allow you to mend roughly with thread.”

vikaṇṇo.comments: The word 'vikaṇṇo' is an adjective derived from the root √kaṇ with the prefix 'vi', indicating a deformation or alteration. In the given sentences, it describes something with deformed corners or edges.

vikaṇṇaṃ.comments: The word 'vikaṇṇa' is used to describe something that is deformed or uneven, particularly in the context of the corners of robes. It is derived from 'vi' (indicating separation or alteration) and 'kaṇṇa' (corner or edge).
vikaṇṇaṃ.translation_1: “I allow you to remove the deformity.”
vikaṇṇaṃ.translation_2: The corners of the robes were deformed.

vinipātetabbaṃ.meaning_2: should be ruined; should be destroyed; should be wasted
vinipātetabbaṃ.comments: The word is a gerundive (passive future participle) formed from the causative of √pat (to fall), with prefixes vi- (intensifying) and ni- (down). In context, it refers to something that should not be ruined or wasted, specifically a 'gift of faith' (saddhādeyyaṁ).
vinipātetabbaṃ.translation_1: But, monks, a gift of faith shouldn’t be ruined.

lūkhacīvarosīti.meaning_2: wearing rough robes; dressed in coarse cloth
lūkhacīvarosīti.comments: The word is a compound of 'lūkha' (rough), 'cīvara' (robe), and 'osī' (wearing), used in the context of describing someone dressed in coarse or rough robes, likely an ascetic.

vassikasaṅketaṃ.meaning_2: the rainy season; the monsoon period
vassikasaṅketaṃ.comments: The word is a compound of 'vassika' (related to the rainy season) and 'saṅketa' (agreement or period). In the given context, it refers to the period of the rainy season when monks traditionally observe retreat.
vassikasaṅketaṃ.example_1: gilāno vā hoti, vassikasaṅketaṁ vā hoti, nadīpāraṁ gantuṁ vā hoti, aggaḷaguttivihāro vā hoti, atthatakathinaṁ vā hoti.
vassikasaṅketaṃ.translation_1: you’re sick; it’s the rainy season; you’re going to cross a river; the dwelling is protected by a door; you have participated in the robe-making ceremony.
vassikasaṅketaṃ.example_2: gilāno vā hoti, vassikasaṅketaṁ vā hoti, nadīpāraṁ gantuṁ vā hoti, aggaḷaguttivihāro vā hoti, atthatakathinaṁ vā hoti.

aggaḷaguttivihāro.meaning_2: the dwelling is protected by a door; the residence is secured with a door
aggaḷaguttivihāro.comments: The compound 'aggaḷaguttivihāro' refers to a dwelling (vihāra) that is protected (gutti) by a door (aggaḷā). This is a descriptive compound (karmadhāraya) where 'aggaḷā' (door) and 'gutti' (protection) together describe the nature of the 'vihāra' (dwelling). The context suggests a practical condition related to monastic rules, likely indicating a permissible reason for certain actions when the dwelling is secured.
aggaḷaguttivihāro.example_1: gilāno vā hoti, vassikasaṅketaṁ vā hoti, nadīpāraṁ gantuṁ vā hoti, aggaḷaguttivihāro vā hoti, atthatakathinaṁ vā hoti.
aggaḷaguttivihāro.translation_1: you’re sick; it’s the rainy season; you’re going to cross a river; the dwelling is protected by a door; you have participated in the robe-making ceremony.
aggaḷaguttivihāro.example_2: gilāno vā hoti, vassikasaṅketaṁ vā hoti, nadīpāraṁ gantuṁ vā hoti, aggaḷaguttivihāro vā hoti, atthatakathinaṁ vā hoti.

saṅghikacīvaruppādakathā.meaning_2: discussion of robe-cloth given to the Sangha; analysis of communal robe distribution
saṅghikacīvaruppādakathā.comments: The compound refers to a Vinaya discussion specifically about robes designated for the Sangha (communal property). The context shows it's a formal analysis of rules regarding such robes.
saṅghikacīvaruppādakathā.translation_1: 21. Discussion of robe-cloth given to the Sangha

apātite.meaning_2: not dropped; not felled; not slain; not killed; lit. not caused to fall
apātite.comments: The word 'apātite' is the negative past participle of 'pāteti' (to cause to fall). In this context, it refers to the robe-cloth not yet being distributed (i.e., not yet 'dropped' or 'assigned'). The negation is formed by the prefix 'a-'.
apātite.example_1: Tehi ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhūhi taṁ cīvaraṁ bhājiyamāne, apātite kuse, añño bhikkhu āgacchati, samako dātabbo bhāgo.
apātite.translation_1: If yet another monk arrives before they’ve distributed that robe-cloth by drawing lots, he too should be given an equal share.

isidāso.meaning_2: Venerable Isidāsa; sage who is not a slave
isidāso.comments: The name 'Isidāsa' appears to be a compound of 'isi' (sage) and 'adāsa' (not a slave), forming a meaningful name 'Sage who is not a slave' or 'Venerable Isidāsa' as a proper name. The context shows it is used as the name of a senior monk.
isidāso.example_1: Tena kho pana samayena dve bhātikā therā, āyasmā ca isidāso āyasmā ca isibhaṭo, sāvatthiyaṁ vassaṁvuṭṭhā aññataraṁ gāmakāvāsaṁ agamaṁsu.
isidāso.translation_1: On one occasion, after completing the rainy-season residence at Sāvatthī, two senior monks who were brothers, Venerable Isidāsa and Venerable Isibhaṭa, went to a certain village monastery.

isibhaṭo.comments: The word appears to be a proper name (of a monk) with honorific elements. The compound suggests 'sage' (isi) + possibly 'servant' or 'devotee' (bhaṭa).
isibhaṭo.example_1: Tena kho pana samayena dve bhātikā therā, āyasmā ca isidāso āyasmā ca isibhaṭo, sāvatthiyaṁ vassaṁvuṭṭhā aññataraṁ gāmakāvāsaṁ agamaṁsu.
isibhaṭo.translation_1: On one occasion, after completing the rainy-season residence at Sāvatthī, two senior monks who were brothers, Venerable Isidāsa and Venerable Isibhaṭa, went to a certain village monastery.

nilavāsī.meaning_2: one who wears blue robes; a monk dressed in blue
nilavāsī.comments: The word 'nilavāsī' is a compound of 'nīla' (blue) and 'vāsī' (one who wears), referring to a monk who wears blue robes. In the given context, it is used as a proper name for a senior monk.
nilavāsī.example_1: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā therā, āyasmā ca nilavāsī āyasmā ca sāṇavāsī āyasmā ca gotako āyasmā ca bhagu āyasmā ca phaḷikasantāno, pāṭaliputte viharanti kukkuṭārāme.
nilavāsī.translation_1: On that occasion there were a number of senior monks—Venerable Nilavāsī, Venerable Sāṇavāsī, Venerable Gotaka, Venerable Bhagu, and Venerable Phaḷikasantāna—staying at Pāṭaliputta in the Kukkuṭa Monastery.

sāṇavāsī.meaning_2: one who wears hemp cloth; a monk who wears robes made of hemp
sāṇavāsī.comments: The term 'sāṇavāsī' is a compound of 'sāṇa' (hemp) and 'vāsī' (wearer), referring to a monk who wears robes made of hemp. This is evident from the context where it is used as a title for Venerable Sāṇavāsī, indicating his ascetic practice of wearing simple hemp cloth.
sāṇavāsī.example_1: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā therā, āyasmā ca nilavāsī āyasmā ca sāṇavāsī āyasmā ca gotako āyasmā ca bhagu āyasmā ca phaḷikasantāno, pāṭaliputte viharanti kukkuṭārāme.
sāṇavāsī.translation_1: On that occasion there were a number of senior monks—Venerable Nilavāsī, Venerable Sāṇavāsī, Venerable Gotaka, Venerable Bhagu, and Venerable Phaḷikasantāna—staying at Pāṭaliputta in the Kukkuṭa Monastery.
sāṇavāsī.example_2: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā sambhūto sāṇavāsī ahogaṅge pabbate paṭivasati.
sāṇavāsī.translation_2: Yasa then traveled to Venerable Sambhūta Sāṇavāsī who was staying on the Ahogaṅga mountain.

gotako.comments: The name 'Gotaka' appears to be derived from the root √gam (to go), possibly indicating someone who is a 'goer' or 'wanderer', common in monastic names.
gotako.example_1: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā therā, āyasmā ca nilavāsī āyasmā ca sāṇavāsī āyasmā ca gotako āyasmā ca bhagu āyasmā ca phaḷikasantāno, pāṭaliputte viharanti kukkuṭārāme.
gotako.translation_1: On that occasion there were a number of senior monks—Venerable Nilavāsī, Venerable Sāṇavāsī, Venerable Gotaka, Venerable Bhagu, and Venerable Phaḷikasantāna—staying at Pāṭaliputta in the Kukkuṭa Monastery.

phaḷikasantāno.meaning_2: Venerable Phaḷikasantāna (a proper name of a monk); one whose lineage is like crystal
phaḷikasantāno.comments: The name appears to be a compound meaning 'one whose lineage (santāna) is like crystal (phaḷika)', possibly indicating purity or clarity of spiritual lineage. It is the name of a senior monk mentioned in the Vinaya context.
phaḷikasantāno.example_1: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā therā, āyasmā ca nilavāsī āyasmā ca sāṇavāsī āyasmā ca gotako āyasmā ca bhagu āyasmā ca phaḷikasantāno, pāṭaliputte viharanti kukkuṭārāme.
phaḷikasantāno.translation_1: On that occasion there were a number of senior monks—Venerable Nilavāsī, Venerable Sāṇavāsī, Venerable Gotaka, Venerable Bhagu, and Venerable Phaḷikasantāna—staying at Pāṭaliputta in the Kukkuṭa Monastery.

upanandasakyaputtavatthu.meaning_2: case of Upananda the Sakyan; story of Upananda the Sakyan
upanandasakyaputtavatthu.comments: This is a compound word referring to a specific case or story involving Upananda, a Sakyan. The context suggests it is a narrative or example from the Vinaya texts.

bhājiyissanti.meaning_2: will be distributed; will be divided; will be shared
bhājiyissanti.comments: The verb is in future passive form (bhājiyissanti), indicating an action that will be done to the subject (the robe-cloth). The context shows a communal distribution of resources within the Sangha.
bhājiyissanti.example_1: Te evamāhaṁsu—“imāni kho, āvuso, saṅghikāni cīvarāni bhājiyissanti, sādiyissasi bhāgan”ti?
bhājiyissanti.translation_1: They said to Upananda, “We’re distributing the Sangha’s robe-cloth. Would you like a share?”
bhājiyissanti.example_2: Tepi evamāhaṁsu—“imāni kho, āvuso, saṅghikāni cīvarāni bhājiyissanti, sādiyissasi bhāgan”ti?
bhājiyissanti.translation_2: They said to Upananda, “We’re distributing the Sangha’s robe-cloth. Would you like a share?”

cīvarabhāgaṃ.meaning_2: share of robe-cloth; portion of robe material
cīvarabhāgaṃ.comments: The compound 'cīvarabhāga' refers to a portion or share of robe-cloth, often distributed among monks. In the given sentences, it is used in the context of monks receiving or taking their allotted portion of robe-cloth, highlighting its practical and communal significance in monastic life.
cīvarabhāgaṃ.example_1: Tato cīvarabhāgaṁ gahetvā aññaṁ āvāsaṁ agamāsi.
cīvarabhāgaṃ.translation_1: He then took that share of robe-cloth and went to another monastery.
cīvarabhāgaṃ.example_2: Tatopi cīvarabhāgaṁ gahetvā aññaṁ āvāsaṁ agamāsi.
cīvarabhāgaṃ.translation_2: He then took that share, too, and went to yet another monastery.

cīvarabhaṇḍikaṃ.meaning_2: bundle of robe-cloth; parcel of robes
cīvarabhaṇḍikaṃ.comments: The word is a compound of 'cīvara' (robe-cloth) and 'bhaṇḍikā' (bundle), referring to a wrapped bundle of robes. The context shows it's a physical object being carried.
cīvarabhaṇḍikaṃ.example_1: Tatopi cīvarabhāgaṁ gahetvā mahantaṁ cīvarabhaṇḍikaṁ ādāya punadeva sāvatthiṁ paccāgañchi.
cīvarabhaṇḍikaṃ.translation_1: He then took that share too, made a large bundle of robe-cloth, and returned to Sāvatthī.

cīvarabhāgo.meaning_2: share of the robe-cloth; portion of the robe
cīvarabhāgo.comments: The compound 'cīvarabhāgo' refers to a share or portion of robe-cloth, which is a key item for monks. In this context, it is prohibited to accept such a share from a place other than where one has spent the rainy-season residence.
cīvarabhāgo.example_1: “na, bhikkhave, aññatra vassaṁvuṭṭhena aññatra cīvarabhāgo sāditabbo.
cīvarabhāgo.translation_1: “You shouldn’t spend the rainy-season residence in one place and then accept a share of the robe-cloth from somewhere else.

ekādhippāyaṃ.comments: The word is a compound of 'eka' (one) and 'adhippāya' (intention/purpose), used here in the context of allocating a single share or portion to a foolish person.
ekādhippāyaṃ.translation_1: “Give the foolish man one person’s share.

gilānavatthukathā.meaning_2: the account of the one who was sick; the case of the sick person; the story about the sick person
gilānavatthukathā.comments: The word is a compound consisting of 'gilāna' (sick), 'vatthu' (case/matter), and 'kathā' (account/story). It refers to a narrative or discussion regarding a sick person, fitting the context of the provided sentence.
gilānavatthukathā.translation_1: 23. The account of the one who was sick

kucchivikārābādho.comments: The compound 'kucchivikārābādha' refers to a stomach-related disorder, specifically dysentery in this context, combining 'kucchi' (stomach), 'vikāra' (disturbance), and 'ābādha' (affliction).
kucchivikārābādho.example_1: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa bhikkhuno kucchivikārābādho hoti.
kucchivikārābādho.translation_1: On one occasion there was a monk who had dysentery

kucchivikāro.comments: The compound 'kucchivikāro' refers to a disorder of the stomach, specifically dysentery, as indicated by the context where the speaker is reporting an illness.

kucchivikārābādhoti.comments: The compound 'kucchivikārābādha' refers to a stomach or intestinal disorder, specifically dysentery in this context. It combines 'kucchi' (stomach), 'vikāra' (disorder), and 'ābādha' (affliction).

dūpaṭṭho.meaning_2: hard to nurse; difficult to care for
dūpaṭṭho.comments: The compound 'dūpaṭṭho' is formed from 'dū' (hard, difficult) and 'paṭṭha' (nursing, care). In the context, it describes a sick person who is difficult to care for due to certain qualities.
dūpaṭṭho.example_1: Pañcahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato gilāno dūpaṭṭho hoti—
dūpaṭṭho.translation_1: “A sick person who has five qualities is hard to nurse:
dūpaṭṭho.example_2: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahaṅgehi samannāgato gilāno dūpaṭṭho hoti.

nāvikattā.meaning_2: acting like a sailor; behaving as a sailor; describing (as a sailor would describe)
nāvikattā.comments: In this context, 'nāvikattā' seems to metaphorically describe someone who is not accurately describing their condition (like a sailor might describe the state of a ship), implying a lack of proper communication about their illness.
nāvikattā.example_1: asappāyakārī hoti, sappāye mattaṁ na jānāti, bhesajjaṁ na paṭisevitā hoti, atthakāmassa gilānupaṭṭhākassa yathābhūtaṁ ābādhaṁ nāvikattā hoti ‘abhikkamantaṁ vā abhikkamatīti, paṭikkamantaṁ vā paṭikkamatīti, ṭhitaṁ vā ṭhito’ti, uppannānaṁ sārīrikānaṁ vedanānaṁ dukkhānaṁ tibbānaṁ kharānaṁ kaṭukānaṁ asātānaṁ amanāpānaṁ pāṇaharānaṁ anadhivāsakajātiko hoti.
nāvikattā.translation_1: they do what’s detrimental for curing the sickness; they don’t know the right amount in what’s beneficial; they don’t take their medicine; they don’t accurately describe the state of their illness—whether it’s getting worse, better, or remaining the same—to the one who’s nursing them and wishing them well; they’re unable to bear up with bodily feelings that are painful, severe, sharp, and life-threatening.

sūpaṭṭho.meaning_2: easy to nurse; well cared for
sūpaṭṭho.comments: The word appears to be a compound of 'sūpa' (soup, nourishment) and 'aṭṭha' (goal, purpose), suggesting someone who is well-nourished or easy to care for in the context of nursing a sick person.
sūpaṭṭho.example_1: Pañcahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato gilāno sūpaṭṭho hoti—
sūpaṭṭho.translation_1: A sick person who has five qualities is easy to nurse:
sūpaṭṭho.example_2: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahaṅgehi samannāgato gilāno sūpaṭṭho hoti.

nīhātuṃ.comments: The word 'nīhātuṃ' is the infinitive form of 'nīharati', meaning 'to remove' or 'to clean up'. In the given context, it refers to the act of cleaning up bodily waste (feces, urine, spit, or vomit) while nursing the sick.
nīhātuṃ.example_1: na paṭibalo hoti bhesajjaṁ saṁvidhātuṁ, sappāyāsappāyaṁ na jānāti, asappāyaṁ upanāmeti sappāyaṁ apanāmeti, āmisantaro gilānaṁ upaṭṭhāti no mettacitto, jegucchī hoti uccāraṁ vā passāvaṁ vā kheḷaṁ vā vantaṁ vā nīhātuṁ, na paṭibalo hoti gilānaṁ kālena kālaṁ dhammiyā kathāya sandassetuṁ samādapetuṁ samuttejetuṁ sampahaṁsetuṁ.
nīhātuṃ.translation_1: they’re incapable of preparing medicine; not knowing what’s beneficial and what’s harmful, they bring what’s harmful and remove what’s beneficial; they nurse the sick for the sake of worldly gain, not with a mind of good will; they’re disgusted at having to clean up feces, urine, spit, or vomit; they’re incapable of instructing, inspiring, and gladdening the sick person with a teaching from time to time.
nīhātuṃ.example_2: paṭibalo hoti bhesajjaṁ saṁvidhātuṁ, sappāyāsappāyaṁ jānāti, asappāyaṁ apanāmeti sappāyaṁ upanāmeti, mettacitto gilānaṁ upaṭṭhāti no āmisantaro, ajegucchī hoti uccāraṁ vā passāvaṁ vā kheḷaṁ vā vantaṁ vā nīhātuṁ, paṭibalo hoti gilānaṁ kālena kālaṁ dhammiyā kathāya sandassetuṁ samādapetuṁ samuttejetuṁ sampahaṁsetuṁ.
nīhātuṃ.translation_2: they’re capable of preparing medicine; knowing what’s beneficial and what’s harmful, they remove what’s harmful and bring what’s beneficial; they nurse the sick with a mind of good will, not for the sake of worldly gain; they’re not disgusted at having to clean up feces, urine, spit, or vomit; they’re capable of instructing, inspiring, and gladdening the sick person with a teaching from time to time.”

matasantakakathā.meaning_2: discussion of inheritance; talk about property of the deceased
matasantakakathā.comments: The compound 'matasantakakathā' refers to a discussion or discourse concerning the inheritance or property left by a deceased person. The context shows it is a specific type of legal or procedural discussion.

lahubhaṇḍaṃ.comments: The compound 'lahubhaṇḍaṃ' refers to lightweight or ordinary possessions, as opposed to more valuable or heavy items. In the context of the Vinaya, it specifies the type of goods to be distributed by the Sangha.
lahubhaṇḍaṃ.example_1: Yaṁ tattha lahubhaṇḍaṁ lahuparikkhāraṁ taṁ sammukhībhūtena saṅghena bhājetuṁ.
lahubhaṇḍaṃ.translation_1: The present Sangha should distribute his ordinary possessions.

lahuparikkhāraṃ.meaning_2: light equipment; ordinary possessions; everyday items
lahuparikkhāraṃ.comments: The compound 'lahuparikkhāra' refers to lightweight or ordinary possessions, as opposed to heavier or more valuable items. In the given context, it is used to describe items that should be distributed by the Sangha.
lahuparikkhāraṃ.example_1: Yaṁ tattha lahubhaṇḍaṁ lahuparikkhāraṁ taṁ sammukhībhūtena saṅghena bhājetuṁ.
lahuparikkhāraṃ.translation_1: The present Sangha should distribute his ordinary possessions.

āgatānāgatassa.meaning_2: present and future; arrived and not arrived
āgatānāgatassa.comments: The compound 'āgatānāgatassa' is a dvanda (copulative) compound combining 'āgata' (come, arrived, present) and 'anāgata' (not come, future). It refers collectively to the Sangha as a whole, both present and future members. The context shows it is used in dedicating property to the Sangha in perpetuity.
āgatānāgatassa.example_1: Yaṁ tattha garubhaṇḍaṁ garuparikkhāraṁ taṁ āgatānāgatassa cātuddisassa saṅghassa avissajjikaṁ avebhaṅgikan”ti.
āgatānāgatassa.translation_1: His valuable possessions are for the Sangha as a whole, both present and future. They’re not to be given out, not to be distributed.”
āgatānāgatassa.example_2: “Tena hi tvaṁ, gahapati, te saṭṭhivihāre āgatānāgatassa cātuddisassa saṅghassa patiṭṭhāpehī”ti.
āgatānāgatassa.translation_2: “Well then, give those sixty dwellings to the Sangha as a whole, both present and future.”

avissajjikaṃ.meaning_2: not to be given out; not to be distributed
avissajjikaṃ.comments: The word is a negative adjective derived from the verb 'vissajjati' (to give out, distribute), with the prefix 'a-' indicating negation. In the context, it describes the valuable possessions of the Sangha that should not be given away or distributed.
avissajjikaṃ.example_1: Yaṁ tattha garubhaṇḍaṁ garuparikkhāraṁ taṁ āgatānāgatassa cātuddisassa saṅghassa avissajjikaṁ avebhaṅgikan”ti.
avissajjikaṃ.translation_1: His valuable possessions are for the Sangha as a whole, both present and future. They’re not to be given out, not to be distributed.”

avebhaṅgikanti.meaning_2: not to be distributed; not to be divided
avebhaṅgikanti.comments: The word is a negative compound (a + vebhaṅga + ika) meaning 'not to be distributed'. In the context of the Vinaya, it refers to communal property of the Sangha that should not be divided or given away.
avebhaṅgikanti.example_1: Yaṁ tattha garubhaṇḍaṁ garuparikkhāraṁ taṁ āgatānāgatassa cātuddisassa saṅghassa avissajjikaṁ avebhaṅgikan”ti.
avebhaṅgikanti.translation_1: His valuable possessions are for the Sangha as a whole, both present and future. They’re not to be given out, not to be distributed.”

naggiyapaṭikkhepakathā.meaning_2: discussion of the prohibition against nakedness; talk on the rejection of nudity
naggiyapaṭikkhepakathā.comments: The compound is a tatpurusa (determinative) compound, where 'kathā' (discussion) is the main element, modified by 'naggiyapaṭikkhepa' (prohibition against nakedness). The context is clearly Vinaya-related, discussing monastic rules.
naggiyapaṭikkhepakathā.translation_1: 25. Discussion of the prohibition against nakedness

kusacīrādipaṭikkhepakathā.meaning_2: discussion of the prohibition against grass robes, etc.; analysis of the rejection of garments made from kusa grass and similar items
kusacīrādipaṭikkhepakathā.comments: The compound refers to a specific discussion in the Vinaya texts regarding the prohibition against wearing robes made from kusa grass and similar materials. The context suggests it is a detailed analysis or commentary on this rule.
kusacīrādipaṭikkhepakathā.translation_1: 26. Discussion of the prohibition against grass robes, etc.

titthiyadhajaṃ.meaning_2: sign of monastics of other religions; emblem of another sect
titthiyadhajaṃ.comments: The compound 'titthiyadhaja' combines 'titthiya' (other sect) and 'dhaja' (flag/symbol), referring to the distinctive emblem or robe worn by monastics of other religions, as criticized in the context.
titthiyadhajaṃ.example_1: Kathañhi nāma tvaṁ, moghapurisa, ajinakkhipaṁ titthiyadhajaṁ dhāressasi.
titthiyadhajaṃ.translation_1: How can you wear a robe made of antelope hide, that sign of monastics of other religions?
titthiyadhajaṃ.translation_2: “You shouldn’t wear a robe made of antelope hide, that sign of monastics of other religions.

akkanāḷaṃ.meaning_2: sarong made of stalks of crown flower
akkanāḷaṃ.comments: The compound 'akkanāḷaṃ' refers to a garment made from the stalks of the crown flower (Calotropis gigantea), as indicated by the context of the sentence. The first part 'akka' refers to the crown flower, and 'nāḷa' refers to its stalk or stem.
akkanāḷaṃ.example_1: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro bhikkhu akkanāḷaṁ nivāsetvā …pe…
akkanāḷaṃ.translation_1: On one occasion a monk dressed in a sarong made of stalks of crown flower …

sabbanīlakādipaṭikkhepakathā.meaning_2: discussion of the prohibition against what is entirely blue, etc.
sabbanīlakādipaṭikkhepakathā.comments: This is a compound word discussing the prohibition against entirely blue items, etc. It is a feminine noun in compound form, combining multiple elements to describe a specific type of discussion in the Vinaya context.
sabbanīlakādipaṭikkhepakathā.translation_1: 27. Discussion of the prohibition against what is entirely blue, etc.

sabbapītakāni.comments: The word is a compound adjective describing robes that are entirely yellow, as seen in the context of monastic clothing regulations.
sabbapītakāni.example_2: “Na, bhikkhave, sabbanīlakāni cīvarāni dhāretabbāni, na sabbapītakāni cīvarāni dhāretabbāni, na sabbalohitakāni cīvarāni dhāretabbāni, na sabbamañjiṭṭhakāni cīvarāni dhāretabbāni, na sabbakaṇhāni cīvarāni dhāretabbāni, na sabbamahāraṅgarattāni cīvarāni dhāretabbāni, na sabbamahānāmarattāni cīvarāni dhāretabbāni, na acchinnadasāni cīvarāni dhāretabbāni, na dīghadasāni cīvarāni dhāretabbāni, na pupphadasāni cīvarāni dhāretabbāni, na phaṇadasāni cīvarāni dhāretabbāni, na kañcukaṁ dhāretabbaṁ, na tirīṭakaṁ dhāretabbaṁ, na veṭhanaṁ dhāretabbaṁ.
sabbapītakāni.translation_2: “You shouldn’t wear entirely blue robes, entirely yellow robes, entirely red robes, entirely magenta robes, entirely black robes, entirely orange robes, entirely beige robes, robes with borders made from a single piece of cloth, robes with long borders, robes with floral borders, robes with borders decorated with snakes’ hoods, close-fitting jackets, Lodh-tree robes, or turbans.

sabbalohitakāni.comments: The compound 'sabbalohitakāni' is used to describe robes that are entirely red, which is explicitly prohibited for monks to wear according to the Vinaya rules.
sabbalohitakāni.example_2: “Na, bhikkhave, sabbanīlakāni cīvarāni dhāretabbāni, na sabbapītakāni cīvarāni dhāretabbāni, na sabbalohitakāni cīvarāni dhāretabbāni, na sabbamañjiṭṭhakāni cīvarāni dhāretabbāni, na sabbakaṇhāni cīvarāni dhāretabbāni, na sabbamahāraṅgarattāni cīvarāni dhāretabbāni, na sabbamahānāmarattāni cīvarāni dhāretabbāni, na acchinnadasāni cīvarāni dhāretabbāni, na dīghadasāni cīvarāni dhāretabbāni, na pupphadasāni cīvarāni dhāretabbāni, na phaṇadasāni cīvarāni dhāretabbāni, na kañcukaṁ dhāretabbaṁ, na tirīṭakaṁ dhāretabbaṁ, na veṭhanaṁ dhāretabbaṁ.
sabbalohitakāni.translation_2: “You shouldn’t wear entirely blue robes, entirely yellow robes, entirely red robes, entirely magenta robes, entirely black robes, entirely orange robes, entirely beige robes, robes with borders made from a single piece of cloth, robes with long borders, robes with floral borders, robes with borders decorated with snakes’ hoods, close-fitting jackets, Lodh-tree robes, or turbans.

vassaṃvuṭṭhānaṃanuppannacīvarakathā.meaning_2: discussion of robe-cloth that has not yet been offered to those who have completed the rainy-season residence; case of robe-cloth not yet arisen for those who have completed the rains
